CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Complex Systems Beijing Key Laboratory of Ionic Liquids Clean Process Institute of Process Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China The development of sustainable catalysts for the conversion of carbon dioxide into value-added chemicals is an effective way to alleviate environmental problems. This study examined the cyclic addition of epoxy propane (PO) and carbon dioxide to propylene carbonate (PC) in a microchannel using a range of imidazol-based deep eutectic ionic liquids (DEILs). By examining the effects of various operating circumstances, such as reaction temperature, operating pressure, residence time, and CO2 to PO molar ratio, the performance of the microreactor was evaluated. According to the findings, the residence time was drastically decreased, going from a few hours in a traditional stirring reactor to just over a minute in a microreactor. The yield of PC could reach 94.23%, and the space-time yield could reach 10.063 g/g/h at 80 °C, 1 MPa, and a residence time of 19 min, while they were 92.32% and 0.406 g/g/h, respectively, for 7 h in a traditional reactor under the same circumstances. It was 24.8 times higher in space-time yield for the microchannel. Graphical abstract Novel imidazole-based deep eutectic ionic liquids (DEILs) suitable for microchannel reactors have been successfully developed and used to efficiently catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions using a microchannel reactor. In addition to having high reactivity, DEIL increases the solubility of ILs in PO/PC system. The yield of The PC was 94.2%, and the space-time yield was 10.06 g/g/h at 80 °C, 1 MPa, and a residence time of 19 min, while it was 92.3% and 0.41 g/g/h, respectively, for 7 h in a typical reactor under the same circumstances. It was 24.8 times higher in space-time yield for the microchannel. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mild condition conversion Deep eutectic ionic liquid Microchannel reactor Cycloaddition reaction Carbon dioxide Carbonate Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In recent years, the greenhouse effect has become increasingly obvious due to the excessive emission of CO2, resulting in many great challenges to the global environment [1–3]. Many countries have taken more steps than ever over on the issue of limiting CO2 emissions. For example, China aims to have a carbon dioxide emissions peak before 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality before 2060 [4]. In addition to reducing CO2 emissions, as an abundant and inexpensive C1 resource, the chemical conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals is also an important way to help realize carbon neutrality [5,6]. Among various CO2-relevant reactions, the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides is one of the most promising ways to utilize CO2, since its atom utilization ratio is 100% and the product, cyclic carbonates, has been one of the widely used high-value chemicals in recent years [7–9]. Cyclic carbonates are important raw materials for many industries, such as new energy batteries, polycarbonate, and intermediates for organic synthesis [10–12]. Many kinds of catalysts have been developed for the cycloaddition reactions of epoxides and CO2 in the past several decades, including metal oxides [13], alkali metal salts [14–16], quaternary onium salts [17,18], ionic liquids [19–24], transition metal complexes [25] and so on. Among these catalysts, ionic liquids (ILs) have been considered one of the most promising catalysts, owing to their advantages, such as high thermal stability, negligible vapor pressure, and structure Designability. Many types of ILs have been used as cycloaddition reaction catalysts, especially functionalized ionic liquids, which usually catalyze reactions without the addition of cocatalysts or organic solvents [26,27]. Although this conversion was possible in the absence of halides and at temperatures below 100 °C, the cyclic carbonates did not convert sufficiently under these conditions [28]. Since then, researchers have added additional functional groups (-NH2, -COOH, -OH, etc.) to ionic liquids in order to stimulate interaction with CO2 or epoxides and thus improve catalytic efficiency [29]. Zhang et al. reported that the hydroxyl‑functionalized ionic liquids (HFILs) exhibited 20% higher activity than the ILs with only alkyl chains [30]. The especially higher activity of HFILs resulted from the hydrogen bond between hydroxyl and epoxides, which reduced the activation energy of ring opening by the attacks of halide anions [31]. Due to the chemical inertness of CO2, cycloaddition reactions of epoxides and CO2 usually require high temperature and pressure conditions to increase the reaction rate, which consumes a large amount of energy [32]. In addition, this reaction is also a typical gas‒liquid heterogeneous reaction, with a large gas‒liquid volume ratio. During the reaction process, a large amount of CO2 first needs to enter the liquid phase through the gas‒liquid mass transfer process. Until then, CO2 could be further converted into carbonates. Therefore, enhancing the gas‒liquid mass-transfer efficiency is a promising way to increase the reaction rate under mild conditions [33]. The mass-transfer rate is usually difficult to improve for traditional reactors, such as agitated reactors and bubble column reactors. Therefore, many researchers use microreactors to improve the mass-transfer rate of the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides [34]. Microreactor technology is perceived as the best strategy of process intensification for chemical synthesis due to its unique characteristics, such as large surface-to-volume ratios, high heat exchanger efficiency and high mass transfer rate [35]. High catalyst concentration had been consistently employed in relevant studies to significantly increase the rate of CO2-epoxy reaction, since microchannel reactors have extraordinarily large mass transfer coefficients (10−5–10−4). Highly polar ionic liquids are poorly soluble(3–10wt%) in the weakly polar solvent PO. This is especially true for imidazole ILs functionalized with hydroxyls and carboxyl groups, which exhibit the solubility as low as 3%. To increase the solubility of the ILs, Wu et al. performed the three-phase gas-liquid reaction in the microchannel using separate feedings of aqueous solutions of ILs and PO, but this did not provide sufficient contact between the ILs and PO [36]. Sun et al. improved the solubility of ILs with the addition of water to PO, but this had the unintended consequence of increasing the selectivity of EG [37]. The strong hydrogen bond brings the higher catalytic activity of ILs but also results in the solid-state of ILs, which reduces the solubility of ILs in epoxides and is inefficient in the liquid phase reaction. To overcome the disadvantages of solid-state ILs, deep eutectic solvents (DEILs) were developed. DEILs were usually in a liquid state [38]. As analogs of ILs, they have also been used as catalysts for CO2 fixation. DEILs have many advantages, such as ease of preparation, high solubility, and excellent catalytic activity. Zhang et al. [39] used DEILs of choline chloride (ChCl) and ZnBr2 to catalyze epoxides and CO2 into cyclic carbonates. Owing to the high solubility and liquid state feature of DEILs, they are very suitable for the catalytic conversion of CO2 and epoxides in microchannel reactors under mild conditions, which usually require high catalyst concentrations. In this study, a kind of imidazole-type deep eutectic ionic liquid (DEIL) catalysts were developed, which was a kind of DEILs synthesized via IL and PG. It solved the problems of low solubility, easy precipitation and low activity of IL in PO, followed by a single-tube helical microchannel reactor to investigate the efficient catalytic synthesis of carbonate by DEILs under mild conditions for the reaction of CO2 and PO, and explored the effects of temperature, pressure, residence time, nCO2/nPO on the PC yield and spatiotemporal yield. In addition, the mass transfer coefficients of the microchannel reactor and the traditional reactor were calculated and compared to reveal the reason of improvement of PC space-time yield (STY). 2 Experimental 2.1 Material PO and 1,2-propanediol (PG)) were purchased from Shanghai Maclean Biochemical Technology Co. CO2 with a purity of 99.99% was purchased from Beijing Analytical Instrument Factory. Ionic liquids used in this work were purchased from Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, including 1-hydroxyethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([(EtOH)MIM]Br) and other imidazolium with different anions or cations. All materials were used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of deep eutectic ionic liquids In the present study, DEILs were synthesized using PG and imidazole ionic liquids (in solid state) in a molar ratio of 2:1. The mixture was stirred at 60 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere for 2–3 h and then dried under vacuum for 12 h to obtain the DEILs, which were in liquid state. It should be noted that the mole of the DEILs in this study is referred to the sum of the moles of the PG and ILs. 2.3 Microchannel reactors and catalytic evaluation The experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1 . The microchannel used in this study was in form of a coiled stainless steel tube, of which the inner diameter, outer diameter, and total length were 2 mm, 3 mm, and 50 m, respectively. The reacting volume of the microchannel reactor was ∼157 cm3. A typical catalytic evaluation in microchannel reactors was as follows. The CO2 and liquid (DEILs:PO:PC =2:7:1) were fed separately, and mixed in a T-mixer before entering the microchannel reactor. The CO2 flow rate was controlled by a gas mass flow controller(the maximum error within ±1%), and the liquid phase feed was controlled by a high-precision pump(the maximum error within ±2%). After reaction in the microchannel, the products flowed into the condenser to condense the epoxide in the system as far as possible. After that, the products flowed into the separation tank to separate the unreacted CO2 and liquid products. The gas and liquid samples were collected to analyze the PO conversions and PC yields. An oil bath was used to control the reaction temperature, and a back pressure valve was used to control the reaction pressure. In this experiment, the internal standard method is used in conjunction with GC to monitor the product after reaction, the use of biphenyl as an internal standard for setting a correction factor. The details could be seen in the supporting information. 2.4 The solubility of DEILs testing ILs were added to the system, sonicated for 5 min, and stirred for 60 min. Then the transparent top layer was took out to titrate the bromide ion contents in T5 excellence titrators of METTLER TOLEDO. In order to titrate for Br− content in T5 excellence titrators set up with AgNO3(0.01 mol/L), 0.5 g of the liquid to be analysed was diluted with an amount of deionised water and performed three times. Once the bromide ion contents was established, the mass fraction of ILs in the PO/PC system was calculated as the solubility. 2.4 Residence time estimation Given that the gas volume continually reduced as the CO2 converting into PC, the liquid flow rate in the tube reduced as well. Therefore, the residence time in the microchannel reactor should be an averaged value, which should take into consideration the initial and final gas flow rates. The residence time (t) was estimated using the Eq. (1.1). (1.1) t = v Q 1 (1.2) Q 1 = Q 2 + Q 3 2 (1.3) Q i = Q G , i + Q L , i i = 2 , 3 where t is the residence time (min), V is the microchannel reactor volume (cm3), and Q 1 is the average gas‒liquid flow rate (cm3/min); Q 2 is the initial gas‒liquid flow(cm3/min); Q 3 is the final gas‒liquid flow (cm3/min); QG is the gas flow rate (cm3/min) and QL is the liquid flow rate (cm3/min). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 DEILs characterization Ten DEILs were synthesized as shown in Table 1. In order to confirm whether DEILs were synthesized and to study the interaction of ILs with PGs, some characterizations were conducted, such as DSC, 1H NMR and FT-IR. Taking [(EtOH)MIM]Br as an example, the DSC curves are shown in the Fig. 2 . The experimental glass transition temperature corresponding to the peak of the glass transition shows that DEIL-4 gives a much lower glass transition point (Tm1=−95.9 ℃) than that given by PG (Tm2=−60 ℃) and [(EtOH)MIM]Br (Tm3=99.7 ℃) alone. While DEIL structures were characterized by the technique of 1H NMR and FT-IR, confirming the hydrogen bonding interactions between ILs and PG. Using DEIL-4 as an illustration, the results of the characterization were examined. It can be seen that the hydrogen atom in H-1 shifts from 9.21 ppm to 9.16 ppm compared to [(EtOH)MIM]Br. And the hydrogen atom in H-9 that is located on the hydroxyl group shifts from low field to high field, indicating the existence of hydrogen bonds between [(EtOH)MIM]Br and PG. As a result of the electrostatic interaction between [(EtOH)MIM]Br and PG, the charge density around the protons on the imidazole ring and the hydroxyl group increases, which amplifies the electron screening effect and results in high-field migration of hydrogen atoms. Based on FT-IR characterization, the hydroxyl groups in [(EtOH)MIM]Br and PG move from 3413 cm−1 and 3370 cm−1 to 3354 cm−1, respectively, while the red shift of the hydroxyl groups indicated the formation of new hydrogen bonding connections (Figs. 3 and 4 ). 3.2 DEIL solubility in the po/pc reaction system In the microchannel reactor, the initial problem is the solubility of the catalyst in solution. After determining the solubility of pure ILs in the system, a variety of DEILs were synthesized in order to improve their solubility in the PO/PC system. Zhang [40] found that the solubility of imidazolyl ionic liquids in pure PO was usually small, which were saturated at a catalyst mass fraction of 5–10 wt%. It was also confirmed by our experiments (Table 2 , row 1). The solubility of ILs with functional groups was even lower in PO. For instance, the solubility of the [(EtOH)MIM]Br in pure PO was only 0.97 wt% (Table 2, row 2). The primary cause of this phenomenon is probably that PO is weakly polar substance, while the ILs are strongly polar substances, leading to a significant difference in polarity between PO and ILs. It poses a challenge to combine PO and ILs with just a single solvent. To greatly increase the solubility of ILs, we thus attacked this problem from two perspectives. On the one hand, a particular amount of PC was added to the PO, to increase the polarity of PO-PC mixture. On the other, to mitigate the high polarity of the ILs and make the catalyst in a liquid state, a series of weakly eutectic ionic liquids were prepared by combining ILs(HBA) with HBD. As shown in Table 2 (row 3–6), the solubility of ILs can be greatly improved by the addition of PC. The solubility of the ILs has increased by a factor of about 25 to 26.3% at PO:PC=1:1. At which point the rate of the reaction is slowed due to the reduced PO content. In addition, it is evident that DEIL formation can significantly increase IL solubility (22.6 wt%). Furthermore, DEIL-7 and PO/PC became mutually solvable systems at PO:PC = 7:1 through the combination of DEILs and PCs. The microchannel reactor would benefit greatly from DEIL-4′s ability to intercalate with it when the molar PO/PC ratio was found to be 7:1. As for other HBD solvents based DEIL, DEIL-9 did not enhance IL solubility. Although, DEIL-10 could also greatly increase the IL solubility, N,N-dimethylformamide was not a component of the reaction system. whereas propylene glycol, which was used in DEIL-4, was a by-product of the system. Therefore, we used the PG based DEILs in further study, and a PO/PC feed ratio of 7:1 was determined. 3.3 Catalytic activity evaluation of different DEILs To investigate the effect of IL structure on catalytic activity of DEIL, eight different DEILs was evaluated in a microchannel reactor. The experiments were performed at 80 °C, 1 MPa, a liquid flow rate Q L of 0.1 mL/min, and a CO2/PO ratio (mol) of 2:1. As shown in Table 3 , although the mean residence times of the reactions were slightly different, owing to the different molecular weights of the ILs, they were all about 20 min. From Entries 1–3, it can be concluded that as the length of the alkyl chain increases, the yield of PC decreases, and the STY decreases as well. From a macroscopic point of view, the DEIL molecular weight will increase due to the growth of chain length. The weight percent of catalyst will increase from 32.7% to 41.4%, indicating that the PO concentration reduced a little. Reducing the concentration of reactants would reduce the rate of reaction. From a microscopic point of view, as the chain length increases, the individual catalyst molecules become larger, the steric hindrance of the cations increases, and the collision frequency between the reactants and the catalyst molecules decreases. In addition, as the length of the chain increases, the polarity of the catalyst decreases, and the interaction with the polar oxygen atoms of the PO decreases as well. Comparing Entry 1 with Entry 4, it can be seen that the polar hydroxyl and carboxyl functional groups can indeed enhance the activity of the catalyst, with DEIL-4 containing hydroxyl functional groups being the most active one, leading to a 16% increase of PC yield. Instead, the addition of amino groups, which are also hydrogen bonded functional groups, decreases catalytic activity. Zhang pointed out that ionic liquids with the most polar carboxyl functional groups were usually the most active ones. Thus, ionic liquids containing carboxyl functional groups should be the most active. However, in this work, based on DEILs based on amine and carboxyl functional groups are less active. The interaction between functional groups and PGs in the PO system is hypothesized to reduce DEIL activity. So, we performed 1H NMR on the PO/PC and PC mixed solutions of the three DEILs, respectively. Hydrogen on hydroxyl groups in DEILs donors with carboxyl functional groups showed greater displacement of hydrogen on the hydroxyl groups, suggesting that ILs and PGs interacted more strongly following PO addition, thus disguising the weakening of ILs and PO interactions leading to reduced activity. In contrast, PG species donating hydrogen bonds to DEIL with a hydroxyl functional group showed no change in the hydrogen shift on the hydroxyl group, suggesting that interaction between ILs and PGs was not increased in the PO system. Hydrogen on the hydroxyl group of PG species, the hydrogen-bond donor of DEIL with the amino functional group, has also shown little change in displacement, but because of its high viscosity it is speculated that the decrease in activity could be due to its physical properties. The details of 1H NMR could be seen in the supporting information. From a comparison of the results of Entries 4 and 7, it could be found that the bromine ion was much more active than the chloride ion. The halogen ions play a very important role in the cycloaddition reaction. They attacked and open the epoxide ring, and the ability of the halogen to leave the ring after the insertion of CO2 also influences the entire catalytic process. On the basis of these findings, we hypothesize that the iodide ion with greater leaving ability would have higher activity. However, since the iodide ion also acted as a catalyst for radical polymerization of hydroxyl containing systems [41], the synthesis process generates a large number of impurities which are difficult to separate. Rendering the less purity and unstable of [(EtOH)MIM]Br catalyst, it was unsuitable for this reaction. On the basis of this, the more stable and active bromine salt was ultimately selected as the anion for IL. The polarization of imidazole 2-H has been reported in the literature as a contributor to the activity of ILs. However, for the DEIL systems. the situation is slightly different. We used the [(EtOH)MIM]Br to synthesize the DEIL-8, which the 2-H in imidazole was substituted by methyl. There was little difference in PC yields between DEIL-1 and DEIL-8, indicating that substitution of imidazole 2-H had little effect on DEIL activity, which might be due to that PG interacts with imidazole 2-H weakening its activation affection. Finally, we selected DEIL-4, the DEIL synthesized from the [(EtOH)MIM]Br) and PG, as the catalyst for the present study. As can been seen in Table 3, DEIL-4 was the most active one, with a 94.2% PC yield at a residence time of 19 min and a STY of 10.06 g/g/h. 3.4 Effect of the residence time All studies were conducted using a molar ratio of DEIL-4:PO:PC=2:7:1 and a molar ratio of CO2/PO of 2 (where the quantity of DEIL-4 material is the total of HBA and HBD, HBA:HBD:PO:PC=2/3:4/3:7:1). The experiments were performed under a mild condition (80 °C, 1 MPa). The liquid flow rate Q L was 0.5–2.1 mL/min, and the CO2/PO=2:1 (mol) was used to determine the flow rate of CO2. The influence of residence time on PC yield and STY were shown in Fig. 5 , which were obtained by adjusting the gas-liquid flow rate. It can be observed that the initial PC yield increases practically linearly and rapidly as the residence time increases at first. However, when PC yield exceeds 94%, the increment rate of PC yield decreases to a very low value. The STY continues to decrease with time while the carbonate selectivity remains nearly constant (>99%). Microchannel reactors exhibit higher mass transfer rate and faster reaction rate, which are influenced by both reaction kinetics and mass transfer. At the beginning of the reaction process, the PO concentration was very high, therefore the reaction rate should be at a high value. However, due to the nature of gas-liquid reaction, the CO2 mass is also a limiting factor of the reaction rate. Although the microchannel reactor exhibits a higher mass transfer rate, it still limits the reaction rate of CO2 and PO by an approximately constant mass transfer rate. Therefore, the PC yield increased almost linearly at the beginning. Once the PO conversion reaches 94%, the concentration of PO became very low, thus the kinetic reaction rate decreased as well. At this time, the high mass transfer rate in microchannel reactor could not improve the reaction since the needed CO2 was enough, while the PO was the insufficient one. In spite of this, compared to the reactions in the traditional stirred reactor, the reaction had shorter residence time of <40 min and higher STY of 5–15 g/g/h. To gain insight into the mass transfer enhancement of microchannel reactors, we performed a comparative experiment in a traditional reactor using DEIL-4 as the catalyst at 80 °C and 1 MPa. DEIL-4 was used to perform identical control assays in accordance with the amount of drug delivered to the microchannel. Reaction times ranged from 20 min to 420 min. Fig. 6 shows that when reaction time increased from 20 min to 420 min, the PC yield rose from 7.8% to 92.3%, and STY fell from 2.17 to 0.41 g/g/h. For a comparison of data of PC yield> 90%, microchannel reactor using 20 min to obtained a PC yield of 94.2% and STY of 10.06 g/g/h. However, for the traditional reactor, the STY was only 0.41 g/g/h, and the PC yield of 92.3% required 7 h to reach. In the microchannel reactor, the retention time was 19 min, the yield of PC was 94.2%, and the STY in the microchannel reactor was 23 times higher than that in the traditional one, indicating a quite difference (higher than an order of magnitude) in the mass transfer efficiency between the microchannel reactor and the autoclave reactor. In order to further confirm the mechanism that mass transfer intensify the reaction efficiency in microchannels significantly, we have measured the mass transfer rate coefficients of the gas‒liquid in the microchannels and the autoclave on the basis of a model in the literature. The gas‒liquid flow conforms to the Lockhart-Martinelli model [42]; that is, the gas and liquid phases flow in the microchannels independently as a single, large continuous phase, and the gas phase is not uniformly mixed as tiny bubbles. According to the pressure drop data obtained from the Lockhart-Martinelli model, Yue et al. [43] predicted the volume mass transfer coefficient kLa on the liquid side during the absorption process in the microchannel according to the energy dissipation model and found that a more accurate prediction model could be obtained by using equations (1.4): (1.4) K L a = 0.0863 ( Δ P F L ) 0.881 where KLa is the liquid-side volume mass transfer coefficient, S −1, and ∆PF is the pressure drop in the microchannel. L is the channel length. The mass transfer coefficient in the reactor was calculated according to the formula. (1.5) ln ( P M − P F P − P F ) = K L a ( P M − P E P F − P E ) t Here, The △PF=0.08 MPa, L = 50 m, PM=1.01 MPa, PF=0.60 MPa, PE=0.21 MPa. Plug P into equation 1.5 and plot t. Obviously the slope is Kla in the autoclave. The mass transfer coefficient was calculated to be 2.971×10−4 s −1 in the microchannel and, 8.229×10−5 s −1 in the autoclave. The Mass transfer coefficient difference is about 4 times. Due to the limitation of experimental conditions, the results have some deviation (Fig. 7 ). 3.5 Effect of the reaction temperature The catalytic activity of DEIL-4 at various reaction temperatures is depicted in Fig. 8 with the condition of 1 MPa, 35–80 °C, 19 min, CO2/PO=2:1. Selectivity was greater than 99%, and the yield of PC increased from 17.3% to 94.2%. As the temperature increased, STY increased from 2.93 g/g/h to 10.06 g/g/h. This finding provides evidence that the temperature plays an important role in accelerating the rate of reaction in a microchannel reactor. It can be seen that the yield of PC was only 17% at 35 °C. As the reaction temperature is increased to 50 °C and 65 °C, the yield of PC increases by only 27% and 48% respectively. When the reaction temperature is increased to 80 °C, however, the yield of PC increases by 94%. This exponential increment was in accordance with Arrhenius' equation. The opening of the PO ring by Br− attack, which is the limiting step in the cycloaddition process, has an activation energy that dictates the overall difficulty of the reaction [44]. Experimental observations from 35 to 80℃demonstrate that, in spite of the microchannel reactor's significant improvement in the mass transfer coefficient, at low temperatures, the activation energy of the reaction still significantly constrains the reaction rate of PO. These results suggest that, within the limits of our current experimental range, there is a mismatch between the fast mass transfer efficiency of the microchannel reactor and the slow kinetic rate of the reaction and that it would be beneficial to raise the reaction temperature to make better use of the fast mass transfer advantages of the microchannel reactor. Despite this, we were still able to achieve a high conversion rate of 94% in only 20 min at 80 °C and 1 MPa, which represented a significant improvement in reaction speed over the 3–10 h reaction time of traditional reactors. 3.6 Effect of the molar ratio of CO2/PO In this section, the liquid-phase flow rate was maintained at 0.1 mL/min and the CO2/PO value varied (1.6–4.5), along with a corresponding change in gas-phase flow rate, ranging from 20 to 100 sccm, in order to investigate the influence of CO2/PO on the cycloaddition process in the microchannel. The residence time would change as the gas-phase flow rate altered. Therefore, in order to maintain residence time, we chose to modify the reactor capacity by varying the tube length. All other reaction parameters were identical to previous experiments. The impact of the CO2/PO ratio on PC yield and STY is depicted in Fig. 9 . It can be seen that the PC yield improved by about 7% as the CO2/PO ratio increased from 1.5 to 2.0, but subsequent increment in CO2/PO ratio had a small effect on the performance. This phenomenon may due to the fact that the specific surface area and the mass transfer would increase as the increase of CO2 flow rate when the gas volume was small. However, when the gas volume was greatly larger the liquid volume, the increment in the specific surface area and the mass transfer would be insignificant. 3.7 Effect of the pressure The effect of pressure (0.5–3 MPa) on yield and STY was further investigated at 80 °C, CO2/PO=2, FL=0.1 ml/min, and a residence time of 19 min. As can be seen in Fig. 10 when the pressure was increased from 0.5 MPa to 1 MPa, there was a noticeable change in PC yield from 79.1% to 94.1% and STY from 8.64 to 10.04 g/g/h. PO has a saturation vapor pressure of 0.3 MPa at 80 °C, the partial pressure of CO2 was 0.3 MPaA at a total pressure of 0.6 MPaA (0.5 MPaG). This resulted in less CO2 in the gas phase, which caused lower CO2 concentration in PO and the reaction to proceed at a slower rate. As the pressure increased to 1.1 MPaA (1 MPaG gauge pressure), it resulted in a significant increase in both the proportion of CO2 in the gas phase and the concentration of CO2 in the liquid phase. It also result in a significant increase in the reaction rate as well. Nevertheless, owing to the high mass transfer rate in microchannel reactors, further increase the CO2 pressure would have smaller effect on the mass transfer and reaction rate [45]. As a result, the increase in PC conversion is no longer statistically significant. 4 Conclusions Novel imidazole-based DEILs suitable for microchannel reactors have been successfully developed and used to efficiently catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions using a microchannel reactors. The fabrication of efficient DEIL and the refinement of the microchannel technique resulted in conversion of propylene oxide (PO) and CO2 to cyclic carbonate at mild condition. Issues of uneven distribution of liquid phases within the microchannel and inadequate solubility of the PO/PC system for single ionic liquids were resolved by the suggested low eutectic ionic liquids and ratios of feed materials, allowing further testing to be carried out. DEIL-4 proved to be the optimate catalyst for the moderate conversion. DEIL-4 reaction condition were then optimized in a microchannel reactor. The impact of a variety of reaction circumstances was studied, and the best reaction condtion for this experiment were generated. The yield of The PC was 94.2%, and the space-time yield was 10.06 g/g/h at 80 °C, 1 MPa, and a residence time of 19 min, while it was 92.3% and 0.41 g/g/h, respectively, for 7 h in a typical reactor under the same circumstances. It was 24.8 times higher in time-space yield for the microchannel. coredata.dc:description: The development of sustainable catalysts for the conversion of carbon dioxide into value-added chemicals is an effective way to alleviate environmental problems. This study examined the cyclic addition of epoxy propane (PO) and carbon dioxide to propylene carbonate (PC) in a microchannel using a range of imidazol-based deep eutectic ionic liquids (DEILs). By examining the effects of various operating circumstances, such as reaction temperature, operating pressure, residence time, and CO2 to PO molar ratio, the performance of the microreactor was evaluated. According to the findings, the residence time was drastically decreased, going from a few hours in a traditional stirring reactor to just over a minute in a microreactor. The yield of PC could reach 94.23%, and the space-time yield could reach 10.063 g/g/h at 80 °C, 1 MPa, and a residence time of 19 min, while they were 92.32% and 0.406 g/g/h, respectively, for 7 h in a traditional reactor under the same circumstances. It was 24.8 times higher in space-time yield for the microchannel.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient synthesis of cyclic carbonate with CO2 under mild condition catalyzed by deep eutectic solvents in a microreactor
